thread.title: More storms on the way as damage bill hits $31M
thread.title_full: More storms on the way as damage bill hits $31M

title: More storms on the way as damage bill hits $31M
text:
Share on Twitter 
SYDNEY is bracing for another series of storms, as the clean-up continues from the weekend’s destructive weather front which brought hail the size of tennis balls and caused $31 million in damage. 
This morning the Insurance Council of Australia declared the weekend’s events a “catastrophe” and said there were 12,000 claims from people who suffered damage to their homes and cars during the storm which brought heavy rain and winds of up to 125km/h. A giant hailstone which landed at Box Hill. Picture: Penrith Storm Chasing Source: Supplied Ben Little and Benji Little (7) were in shock when a hailstone shattered the windscreen of their car at Rouse Hill. Source: News Corp Australia 
And for those still mopping up there is more pain on the way with further storms expected to batter Sydney Friday and into the weekend. 
Bureau of Meteorology Duty Forecaster Andrew Haigh said it was likely storms would hit Sydney again on Friday and over the weekend. Hailstones seen in western Sydney on Saturday. AAP. Source: AAP 
“There is a front expected to move through on Friday and expected to be a focal point for thunderstorms later in the week,” he said. 
He said it was too early to tell if the forecast storms would bring devastating hail which pummelled the city over the weekend. 
“The storms on Saturday, they were pretty high end storms, which you don’t get every week,” he said. Nia Brown and boyfriend Ryan Spears were hit by hail in Rouse Hill during the storm. Source: News Corp Australia #Insurance Council declares Catastrophe for #Sydney #hailstorms 12,000 claims $31m insurance losses. Recovery tips https://t.co/pUwtAHgcwe — Insurance Council (@ICAUS) February 19, 2017 The storm hits Sydney. Picture: Jonathan Ng Source: News Corp Australia
